narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much in this class. While a lot of it was technically review (I took French throughout middle and high school), particularly of common tenses and some grammar, I felt like I actually learned it this time aroundcoming out of the class, I feel the most proficient in French that I've ever felt.

I improved my French listening/speaking a lot through a lot of oral exercises and assigned movies, and learned a lot of new grammatical structures. I also improved my reading by reading several novels for this class.

I improved my reading abilities in French significantly. Going into this class, I hadn't read an entire book in French before, and French 130 gave me a lot of practice. I also noticed that I was better able to understand French when heard aloud.
We read books and watched films in French.
I definitely improved by speaking and writing abilities in French.
I  learned how to read French books and further expanded my knowledge about various tenses and french rules. I improved my french immensely.
I learned proper French grammar and how to speak
Literary skills involving the French language and answering questions about books and movies from class.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class is a lot of work, which I think is both its strength and its weakness. Obviously, a heavy workload is not what you like to read about when you're trolling CourseTable, but in all honesty, I think that a lot of work is simply what it takes to actually learn the language. Other strengths of the course include the material, which was all generally interesting and enjoyable (though we could have engaged with books and films from a wider range of the French diasporaalmost all of the material was based in Paris), the in-class discussion (you really do have to speak, typically at least once per class), and the sense of community that you form with your peers and the professor (this is perhaps the only online course that I've took where I feel like I'll recognize my classmates around campus next fall). In terms of weaknesses, I'd say that the biggest one is the audio programsthough occasionally helpful in their simplistic repetition and pattern-drilling, I often found myself simply tuning them out, or filling in the blanks but not really absorbing the information in any lasting way. While these programs weren't that much of a hindrance, they could also occasionally take up to an hour, and at the end of them, I often felt like I hadn't really learned much and had simply wasted an hour of my time.

This course has a high workload, but the workload definitely helps improve your French. The expectations can sometimes be unclear at the beginning of the course, but over the course of the semester, it become more and more clear.

As mentioned in the question about what knowledge I acquired, I think a strength of this class is that it allows one to greatly improve their French reading skills. A weakness of the course was the lack of speaking practice. In French 120, there was a project that required presenting to the class, which forced me to practice my pronunciation. I think French 130 would benefit from a project like this, because I felt underprepared going into the oral portion of the final exam.
The class meets every day, which is great for language learning. But there can be a lot work every day as well.
A lot of good books and movies that I felt were very conducive to my learning.
a lot of work
Penalization for missing one class/assignment is too high

Strengths: Madame Koundi is a great teacher, the books we read are interesting, the tests are fair. 
Weaknesses: The Jules et Jim unit was a bit long.
I really enjoyed the format of the course. I liked that we would read a book or watch a movie outside of class and the. Talk about it in class

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was one of the better courses I took onlineas a class that is largely discussion-based, in which a whiteboard or lecture slides aren't really needed, the online format wasn't much of hindrance. I do think it would of course be better in-person, but on the whole I felt like discussion could still be engaging and uncomplicated, even over Zoom.
Instruction over Zoom and test over zoom were as good as they could be.
Given the pandemic, this course was structured very effectively.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to other students. Though I think most students simply take it as a part of the language requirement, I did genuinely enjoy it, heavy workload and all, and I feel like I actually learned how to read, think, and speak French more fluidly and naturally than I had before. I would recommend taking it as a part of a lighter workload, however, simply because the homework takes a significant amount of time and you have work pretty much every dayI took it as part of a 4.5-credit semester, for instance, and I think I would have been a lot more stressed out and would have taken less away had I take it as part of a 5 or 5.5-credit semester.

I would recommend this course if you really want to improve your French. Don't expect it to be easy, but no French classes at Yale really are. The workload is high, but you get more out of the class if you do all the work.
Yes, if you love French!
Yes.
Only take french if you have to or like it
Yes. I personally enjoyed FREN 130 way more than FREN 120, and I learned a lot of french. If you like French, then take it, and take it with Madame Koundi.
If you want to get better at French I highly recommend this course, but if you have little or no interest in the language you will not enjoy it
